questions.text: During harvest season, a farmer was taking rest in shade. He felt something biting and woke up to see it moving away quickly. He felt drowsy, pain and uncontrolled bleeding from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following was the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Above features is highly suggestive of viper bite.

Types of venom:

Neurotoxic - Cobra, krait

Hemotoxic - Vipers

Myotoxic - Sea snakes

FEATURES OF VIPER BITE

  • The viperine venom is mainly haemolytic and causes intravascular haemolysis and depression of the coagulation mechanism.
  • The area around the bite is red and painful. The onset of swelling starts within fifteen minutes and there is often blood-stained discharge from the wound. Persistent bleeding from bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in about 12 hours in and around the bite site, progressing subsequently to involve the entire limb.
  • Haematuria may be seen within a few hours of the bite. Prominent features are shock and haemorrhage.
  • In about 10 to 15% of the cases, extensive necrosis of skin, subcutaneous tissues and muscles may occur followed by epistaxis, haemoptysis, ecchymoses, intracranial and subconjunctival haemorrhages, and bleeding into the floor of the mouth, tympanic membrane, gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract, retroperitoneum and intraperitoneum. In severe cases, the main feature is the persisting shock.
  • Bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. A haemorrhagic syndrome with blood-stained sputum, haemorrhages from the gums, rectum, the site of bite, etc., occur due to the increased coagulation time. Intravascular haemolysis may lead to haemoglobinuria.
  • In the case of Russell's viper and hump-nosed viper, renal failure is a frequent complication. Petechial haemorrhages are common. Death is usually due haemorrhage.

FEATURES OF COBRA BITE

  • Local symptoms start within 6 to 8 minutes. A small reddish wheal develops at the site of bite. The bitten area is tender with slight radiating burning pain and oozing of bloodstained fluid. Swelling may be minimal or even absent.
  • The patient feels sleepy, slightly intoxicated, weakness of legs and is reluctant to stand or move. Ptosis is the earliest neuroparalytic manifestation followed by ophthalmoplegia. There may be extraocular muscle weakness and strabismus.
  • Weakness of the muscles increases and develops into paralysis of the lower limbs. The paralysis then spreads to the trunk and affects the head which falls forward. The eyelids also hang down. After half to one hour, there is excessive salivation and even vomiting, headache, vertigo, paraesthesia around the mouth and myalgia. This is followed by paralysis of the facial muscles, palate, jaws, tongue, vocal cords, neck muscles. Muscles of deglutition become progressively flaccidly paralysed due to which there is difficulty in speech and swallowing. After about two hours, the paralysis is complete.
  • Respiratory arrest may occur due to obstruction of upper airway by the paralysed tongue or inhaled vomitus or due to paralysis of intercostal muscles and diaphragm. Coma sets in and finally the respirations stop with or without convulsions and the heart stops.

FEATURES OF KRAIT BITE

  • Symptoms resemble those of cobra bite, but there is no swelling or burning pain at the site of the bite and the convulsions are milder, while the feeling of drowsiness and intoxication is more intense. Albumin appears in urine.

FEATURES OF SCORPION STING

  • This venom contains neurotoxins that cause sodium channels to remain open. Such envenomation usually are associated with little swelling, but prominent pain, paraesthesia and hyperesthesia can be accentuated by tapping on the affected area (the tap test).
  • These symptoms soon spread to other locations; dysfunction of cranial nerves and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles develop within hours. Patients present with restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse salivation, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, slurred speech, difficulty in handling secretions, diaphoresis, nausea, and vomiting. Muscle twitching, jerking and shaking may be mistaken for a seizure.
  • Complications include tachycardia, arrhythmias, hypertension, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, and acidosis. Fatal respiratory arrest is most common among young children and the elderly.

FEATURES OF WASP BITE

  • Wasp venom is composed of biogenic amines like histamine, serotonin, acetylcholine, enzymes like Phospholipase A and B, hyaluronidase, toxic peptides etc.
  • Clinical Features: Local- Pain, redness, swelling
  • Systemic: Person allergic to venom may develop anaphylaxis - Tingling sensation, flushing, dizziness, syncope, vomiting and diarrhoea, wheezing, urticaria, angioedema, renal failure, haemolysis with haemoglobinuria, rhabdomyolysis etc.

questions.text: In a court trial, leading questions are not permitted in all the following except
questions.solution:
In a court trial, leading questions are permitted during cross examination as per Sec. 146(4) BSA

  • A leading question is one which suggests to the witness the answer desired, or which includes a material fact and admits of a conclusive answer by a simple "Yes" or "No" [S.146(1) BSA)].
  • Leading questions are permissible during cross-examination [S.146(4) BSA].
  • In case of chief (direct) examination and re-examination, leading questions are not allowed, except in those cases, where the Judge is satisfied that a witness is hostile [S.146(2) & (3) and Sec. 157 BSA]. The Judge can always disallow irrelevant questions.
  • Leading questions should not be put while recording dying declaration.

questions.text: The onus of proof in civil negligence case against a doctor lies with?
questions.solution:
BURDEN OF PROOF

  • Ordinarily, the task of proving negligence rests upon the plaintiff/patient and it follows therefore that in medical cases it is for the patient or his relatives to establish his claim and not for the doctor to show that he acted with due care and skill.
  • There are, however, certain cases, when the plaintiff need not prove that and the inference of presumption of negligence is drawn from the facts of the case, known as 'res ipsa loquitur'.

Essentials of 'Res Ipsa Loquitur'.

  1. Nature of injury or damage, suggested by common knowledge or inferred from expert evidence, that without negligence, it does not occur.
  2. The defendant must be in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances. The error in such cases is so obvious that the defendant has to establish his innocence.
  3. The plaintiff must not contribute to his own injury or damage.

'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person 'Z' saw 'A' with knife in the park few minutes before murder. 'Z' gives this statement in court of law. What kind of evidence is it?
questions.solution:
ORAL EVIDENCE

  1. Direct: Evidence of a fact which is actually in issue, e.g., an electric blanket that has caused injury, prescription, or a consent form.
  2. Indirect or Circumstantial: It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness, but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent, e.g., in case of alleged murder of A by B at certain place on a particular day and time, the circumstantial evidence would be that C saw B with a knife on that day at that place, a few minutes before the murder. Circumstantial evidence requires the Court to draw logical or reasonable inferences from the information presented.
  3. Hearsay: It is any statement made by any person about what he did not personally witness, or evidence he obtained from a third party, which is presented in the Court in order to assert that the facts contained in the statement are true, e.g., A gives evidence in the witness box stating that B had informed him that he had seen C committing a crime. In such case direct evidence can be given only by B that he had seen C committing a crime.

questions.text:
In a case of sea water drowning, which of the following abnormalities are noted
1. Hyponatremia
2. Hypernatremia
3. Haemoconcentration
4. Hyperkalaemia
5. Cardiac arrhythmia
questions.solution:
When freshwater (hypotonic to plasma) enters the alveolar spaces, it is rapidly absorbed into the pulmonary circulation resulting in gross hemodilution. This massive increase in blood volume leads to hemolysis with the liberation of potassium. This causes hyperkalemia with corresponding dilutional hyponatremia. Hyperkalemia leads to ventricular fibrillation.

When seawater enters, due to high saline content, reverse osmotic flow occurs. The fluid leaves the circulation and enters the alveolar spaces. This causes hemoconcentration, hypernatremia and pulmonary edema. Hypernatremia leads to bradycardia and cardiac arrest.

Bradycardia is a type of abnormal heart rhythm, or arrhythmia.

questions.text: After obtaining informed consent for the management of uterine fibroid, ureter is injured intraoperatively during hysterectomy operation. This is covered under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
During hysterectomy, a doctor is not supposed to injure the ureter. He should have taken proper precautions not to injure the ureter.

(A) Res ipsa loquitor

Ordinarily, the professional negligence of a physician must be proved in Court by the expert evidence of another physician. The patient need not prove negligence in case where the rule of res ipsa loquitur applies, which means "the thing or fact speaks for itself". The patient has to merely state what according to him was the act of negligence.

Conditions to be satisfied:

  1. That in the absence of negligence the injury would not have occurred ordinarily.
  2. That the doctor had exclusive control over the injury producing instrument or treatment.
  3. That the patient was not guilty of contributory negligence.

This enables the patient's lawyer to prove his case without medical evidence.

Examples:

  1. Prescribing an overdose of medicine producing ill-effects.
  2. Giving poisonous medicine carelessly.
  3. Failure to give anti-tetanic serum in cases of injury causing tetanus.
  4. Burns from application of hot water bottles or from X-ray therapy.
  5. Breaking of needles.
  6. Failure to remove the swabs/instruments during operation which may lead to complications or cause death.
  7. Blood transfusion misadventure.
  8. Loss of use of hand due to prolonged splinting.

Application: This doctrine is applied both to civil and criminal negligence. It does not apply where common knowledge or experience is not sufficiently extensive to know that the patient's condition would not have existed but for the doctor's negligence. It cannot be applied against several defendants only one of whom, who cannot be identified could have caused patient's injury.

Novus actus interveniens:

A person is responsible not only for his actions, but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury when continuity of events is broken by an entirely new and unexpected happening, due to negligence of some other person. If the doctor is negligent, which results in a deviation from the logical sequence of events, then the responsibility for he subsequent disability or death may pass from the original incident to the later negligent action of the doctor.

In this case, doctor has taken every measure to avoid the injury but still injury occurred, hence it is a case of Medical mal occurrence.

Therapeutic misadventure:

A misadventure is mischance or accident or disaster. Misadventure is of three types:

  1. Therapeutic (when treatment is being given).
  2. Diagnostic (where diagnosis only is the objective at the time).
  3. Experimental (where the patient has agreed to serve as a subject in an experimental study).

E.g., Pt. dies of anaphylactic shock for the test dose itself.

Medical mal occurrence

In spite of good medical attention and care, individual fails to respond properly or may suffer from adverse reactions of the drug. This is called medical mal occurrence. The injured person cannot get monetary compensation in every mishap or accident which results in injury, if the doctor was careful and has taken appropriate measures to overcome the undesirable foreseeable effects.

Accident can be defined as an unpredictable event resulting in a recognisable injury.

Inevitable accident is an accident not avoidable by any such precautions, as a reasonable man can be expected to take for e.g. breaking of a needle during intramuscular injection due to sudden muscular spasm, or damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve during thyroidectomy

questions.text: What is the retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm known as?
questions.solution:
The retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm is known as back spatter.

In contact shots and sometimes in close shots, the muzzle blast and the negative pressure in the barrel following discharge may suck blood, hair, fragments of tissues and cloth fibres several cm. back inside the barrel called "back spatter" → Helps in identification of weapon.

Forward spatter: Splashing of blood & tissue fragments through the wound of exit.


Option A: Blowback phenomenon: This is seen at the entry wound in a contact shot against a bone, where the gases rebound against the bone and exit through the entry wound, creating a stellate shaped margin at the entry wound.

Option B & C: Retro dispersion and backward scatter are not effects seen in firearm injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early sign of death?
questions.solution:
• Rigor mortis is an early sign of death.
  • Immediate signs of death (somatic death):
    • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    • Cessation of respiration
    • Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death (cellular death):
    • Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    • Eye changes
    • Primary flaccidity of muscles
    • Cooling of the body
    • Postmortem lividity/suggillation
    • Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    • Putrefaction
    • Adipocere
    • Mummification

Rigor mortis or postmortem rigidity or cadaveric rigidity refers to the stiffness of the muscles and joints of the body after the death of an individual. After the first stage of primary relaxation of muscles, the second stage in muscles is the stage of rigor mortis which is followed by the third stage of secondary relaxation due to putrefaction. Rigor mortis occurs because of the chemical changes (Depletion of ATP) in the muscles leading to stiffening of the muscles.

questions.text: 'En masse' removal of organs in autopsy is which technique?
questions.solution:
Evisceration Methods (Techniques of autopsy) :

  1. Letulle's technique:
    • Described by Letulle.
    • Also known as, 'En masse' or 'En bloc' dissection
    • En masse = In a group; all together
    • En bloc = All together or all at the same time
    • In this technique, oral, cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one large organ block.
    • Leaves all attachments intact.
    • Commonly done in medical colleges to teach students
  2. Virchow's Method:
    • Organ by organ removal
    • Individual organ removal one by one.
    • Subsequent dissection of isolated organs.
    • Useful for assessing individual organ pathology.
    • Quick and effective for single organ focus.
    • Most common method in India
  3. Gohn's technique:
    • Developed by Ghon.
    • Also known as, 'Block by block' dissection
    • Cervical & thoracic organs, abdominal organs and the urogenital system are removed as separate organ blocks.
  4. In Situ Dissection:
    • Developed by Rokitansky.
    • Also known as In-situ dissection
    • Organs dissected in situ with minimal evisceration.
    • Rarely performed.
    • Done in infected & suspected infection cases.

questions.text: You notice the given findings on the body on which you have to perform autopsy. Which test can be used to differentiate this from antemortem bruising?
questions.solution:
The given image shows postmortem hypostasis.

The classic test used to differentiate a bruise from hypostasis is the incision test.

The suspected area is incised to see if the underlying blood is intravascular (hypostasis) or infiltrating the tissues outside the vessels(bruise/contusion).

Hypostasis: On incision blood is seen in blood vessels, which can be easily washed away. Subcutaneous tissues are pale.

Bruises: Shows extravasation of blood into the surrounding tissues, which is firmly clotted and cannot be washed by gentle stream of water. Subcutaneous tissues are deep reddish black.

Option A: Getter's chloride test is used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. It is not widely used now.

Option C: In the precipitin test, a specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid, blood, or saliva. A positive test will confirm human origin.

Option D: Breslau's second life test is done to determine whether a child was born alive or not.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man collapsed suddenly during dinner with his friends. They brought him to the ER but he was already dead. On asking further history, they revealed that they were drinking before having food. There were no signs of asphyxia, but on autopsy, a bolus of food lodging in the larynx was found. Which of the following statements about this syndrome is true?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is most likely suggestive of cafe coronary syndrome. Death in cafe coronary syndrome occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity. It is sudden and unexpected and happens rapidly.

'CAFE CORONARY' SYNDROME':

  • A popular term 'cafe coronary' was coined by Dr. Roger Haugen, Medical Examiner of Broward County, Florida for such impaction of food in the respiratory passage.
  • The victim may be observed slumping over the dining table or collapsing suddenly while walking across the room after having meals, with no signs of respiratory distress or any of the 'classic signs of asphyxia'.
  • The original series of deaths involved well-nourished businessmen dying suddenly and unexpectedly in restaurants and cafes, while sitting or shortly after sitting in their chairs, as if they died of heart attack. Hence, the name 'cafe coronary'.
  • However, autopsy usually reveals a bolus of food in the pharynx or larynx. Many cases have been reported where the victim was merely seen dead while sitting or just after sitting in a chair, the mode of death probably being cardiac arrest due to overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system through the stimulation of branches of vagus nerve supplying the laryngeal and/or pharyngeal mucosa.
  • Fairly high level of alcohol has been found in most cases of cafe coronary deaths. The suppression of gag reflex due to alcohol or drugs makes the individual susceptible to this calamity.
  • Senile persons in retirement homes and mentally retarded children in institutions are also vulnerable.

questions.text: Hide and die syndrome occurs in:
questions.solution:
'Hide and die' syndrome:

  • In some hypothermic deaths, bodies are found in some strange places-under a bed or bench, on a shelf or behind a wardrobe, or alternatively may pull down household articles into a heap on top, which may give the impression of their attempt to 'hide' (protective 'burrow-like' or 'cave-like' situation).
  • This may also lead to the assumption of a homicide or robbery. It is due to mental confusion from hypothermia and may be related to hibernation reflex.

An apparent self-protective behaviour, known as "terminal burrowing", or "hide-and-die syndrome", occurs in the final stages of hypothermia. Those affected will enter small, enclosed spaces, such as underneath beds or behind wardrobes. It is often associated with paradoxical undressing

questions.text: A man walks into the ER with a knife sticking out of his heart. He is likely to survive this injury if the knife has penetrated which of the following chambers?
questions.solution:
The patient would survive the injury if it penetrates the left ventricle. In this chamber, the contraction of the layered thick wall may partly or wholly seal the wound, and bleeding can be slight. Hence, chances of survival are high when compared to other chambers of the heart..

The right ventricle is more commonly injured by a stab wound as it presents the largest frontal area. The injury to the right ventricle usually leads to copious bleeding into the pericardial sac. It is because of the inability of the thin wall to close the defect by muscle overlap and contraction.

questions.text: You are performing an autopsy on a fetus born dead at 6 months. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Adipocere formation is not seen in a dead born fetus of 6 months.

Dead-born child:

A dead-born child is a child, which has died in utero and may or may not show the signs of

  1. Rigor mortis
  2. Maceration
  3. Mummification or
  4. Putrefaction

Adipocere

  • Adipocere is a modification of putrefaction.
  • It is due to postmortem hydrolysis or hydrogenation of the fats.
  • In this, the fatty tissues of the body change into a substance known as adipocere which is soft greyish-white, waxy, greasy material with an offensive, sweet rancid smell.
  • It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environment.
  • Foetuses under 7 months do not show this change.

Mummification: It is a process of drying and desiccation of the fetus died in utero and has remained in the uterus for a few days with deficient blood supply, scanty liquor amnii with exclusion of air. Takes about 2 weeks.

Putrefaction: Seen in a fetus died in utero, with ruptured membrane, where air gains entry.

Resorption: If the pregnancy with the dead foetus continues, it may be gradually resorbed.

The most important post-mortem change in an intrauterine death is maceration, which is an autolytic process by which there is self-disintegration of the body by cellular enzymes.

questions.text: Bluish discoloration of gastric mucosa seen in poisoning with:
Vitamin deficiency seen in alcoholic with dementia is:
questions.solution:
Chronic alcoholics may have severe thiamine (Vitamin B-1) deficiency, which may give rise to a condition called Korsakoff’s psychosis which manifests with impairment of short- term memory (dementia) along with compensatory confabulation.

KORSAKOFF'S PSYCHOSIS

Korsakoff's psychosis often follows Wernicke's encephalopathy, so they are referred to as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Cause: Severe, untreated thiamine deficiency, secondary to chronic alcohol abuse.

Signs and Symptoms:

It presents as an organic amnestic syndrome, characterized by:

  • Inability to learn new information,
  • Impairment of short- term memory
  • Compensatory confabulation.

The pathological lesion is usually widespread, but changes are seen in bilateral dorsomedial nuclei of thalamus and mammillary bodies. The changes are also seen in periventricular and periaqueductal grey matter, cerebellum and parts of brainstem.

Sometimes, alcohol dementia may be associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is caused by long-term or excessive drinking resulting in neurological damage and impairment of memory.

questions.text: The usual fatal dose of white phosphorous:
questions.solution:
The usual fatal dose of white phosphorous is 60-120 mg.

  • Fulminating poisoning (death within 12 hours) may be seen when the patient takes a large dose.
  • Early death is due to cardiac dysrhythmias, secondary to electrolyte abnormalities, such as hypocalcaemia and hyperkalaemia.
  • Death after the first 24 h is due to hepatic failure.

Fatal dose: 60-120 mg (1 mg/kg) of white phosphorus.

Fatal period: Within 24 hours but may be delayed by 5-7 days.

Diagnosis: Oral and skin burns, luminescent 'smoking' vomitus and stools with a garlic odour, and GIT and biliary damage characterize white phosphorus poisoning.

questions.text:
The antidote for cyanide toxicity is
i. Sodium nitrite
ii. Sodium thiosulfate
iii. Glyceryl trinitrate
iv. Amyl nitrite
questions.solution:
1. Sodium Nitrite:
    • Mechanism: Sodium nitrite acts by converting hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome c oxidase (the enzyme inhibited by cyanide). This allows methemoglobin to bind cyanide, reducing its toxic effects and facilitating its detoxification.
    • Administration: Typically given intravenously in acute settings.
  2. Sodium Thiosulfate:
    • Mechanism: Sodium thiosulfate serves as a sulfur donor, enhancing the conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and can be excreted in urine. This process is facilitated by the enzyme rhodanese, which is present in the liver.
    • Administration: Often administered intravenously, either alone or in combination with sodium nitrite.
  3. Glyceryl Trinitrate:
    • This is primarily a vasodilator used in the treatment of angina and heart failure. It does not have a direct role in treating cyanide toxicity.
  4. Amyl Nitrite:
    • Mechanism: Like sodium nitrite, amyl nitrite converts hemoglobin to methemoglobin and is used as a rapid-acting antidote in cyanide poisoning. It is often used in emergency settings when intravenous access is not available.
    • Administration: Typically inhaled, providing quick action.

Recommended Combinations for Treatment

The standard treatment protocol for cyanide poisoning often involves using a combination of sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate. Sometimes, amyl nitrite may be used as an initial measure before intravenous access is established.

Answer

Given the roles of these agents in treating cyanide toxicity, the correct answer to the query regarding which antidotes are associated with cyanide toxicity is

b) i, ii This option includes sodium nitrite and sodium thiosulfate, which are both effective antidotes for cyanide poisoning. Amyl nitrite is also effective but is not always included in the standard treatment protocol as a primary agent. Glyceryl trinitrate is not associated with the treatment of cyanide toxicity.

Treatment Procedure Overview

  1. Initial Assessment:
    • Confirm cyanide exposure based on clinical signs and symptoms (e.g., headache, dizziness, shortness of breath, confusion).
  2. Remove from Exposure:
    • Ensure the patient is moved away from the source of cyanide exposure to prevent further harm.
  3. Supportive Care:
    • Administer 100% oxygen to improve oxygenation and combat hypoxia.
  4. Administer Antidotes:
    • Sodium Nitrite: Administer intravenously to form methemoglobin.
    • Sodium Thiosulfate: Administer intravenously to facilitate the conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate.
  5. Monitoring:
    • Continuous monitoring of vital signs and neurological status is crucial. Be prepared for potential complications, such as hypotension due to nitrite administration.
  6. Follow-Up Care:
    • After initial treatment, patients may require further observation and supportive care, especially if they present with severe symptoms

True about snake bite and ASV
1.Lower dose in infant as compared to adults
2.Sensitivity test must be done before ASV
3.Useful for venom associated coagulopathy in viper bites
4.Cobra venom acts at presynaptic region
5.Common krait venom causes both internal and external ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
ASV is useful for venom associated coagulopathy in viper bites; as the viper venom is hemotoxic in nature. Common krait venom is neurotoxic which causes both internal and external ophthalmoplegia manifesting with ptosis.

Children and pregnant women receive the same ASV dosage as adults. The ASV is targeted at neutralizing the venom. Snakes inject the same amount of venom into adults and children.

No ASV test dose must be administered:Test doses have been shown to have no predictive value in detecting anaphylactic or late serum reactions and should not be used. These reactions are not IgE mediated but Complement activated, They may also pre-sensitize the patient and thereby create greater risk.

Common cobra → neurotoxins get fixed at post synaptic region.Hence, neostigmine has a role.
